findings: The feature consistently activates across large multi-domain synthase/synthetase genes, particularly showing strong activation patterns along the entire length of non-ribosomal peptide synthetases (e.g., solG in Xenorhabdus) and related enzymes such as amino acid adenylation domains in Frankia. These enzymes share common domain structures with repeated modules for substrate incorporation.
conclusion: This feature robustly captures a biologically meaningful pattern specific to modular biosynthetic enzymes involved in secondary metabolism, particularly non-ribosomal peptide synthetases.
title: Modular Biosynthetic Enzyme Feature
description: This feature detects sequence patterns characteristic of modular biosynthetic enzymes, particularly non-ribosomal peptide synthetases (NRPS) and related multi-domain synthetases. The activation pattern shows distributed spikes throughout these large genes rather than at boundaries, suggesting the feature recognizes repeated structural elements or conserved catalytic domains common in these enzymes. These enzymes are responsible for synthesizing secondary metabolites including antibiotics and other bioactive compounds. The pattern is highly consistent across diverse bacterial genomes, appearing in the solG NRPS of Xenorhabdus, amino acid adenylation domains in Frankia, and similar large biosynthetic genes in other bacteria. The feature likely captures conserved sequence patterns associated with the modular architecture of these enzymes, which typically contain multiple catalytic domains arranged in assembly-line fashion.
